text: We're doing an article on a subjective topic, and thought we would bring in an expert to give their view. I reached out to two people and both said yes. Is it best to feature only one expert (and therefore increasing the chance they share with their network), or should I include both? :thinking_face:

text:
Hey all, I'm doing customer/audience research for a company in the UK -- does anyone have tips for honing in on customers in a specific overseas market when doing this research online? (I'm in the U.S.) I want to make sure I give them accurate info.

For reference, I'm looking into customer communities (i.e. forums, Facebook groups, subreddits, Instagram hashtags/accounts), reading product reviews for similar products and doing keyword research with Ahrefs.

TIA!

elements.text:
Hey all, I'm doing customer/audience research for a company in the UK -- does anyone have tips for honing in on customers in a specific overseas market when doing this research online? (I'm in the U.S.) I want to make sure I give them accurate info.

For reference, I'm looking into customer communities (i.e. forums, Facebook groups, subreddits, Instagram hashtags/accounts), reading product reviews for similar products and doing keyword research with Ahrefs.

TIA!

text: Yeah I think writing two different articles would be better. But on a totally different topic that they still have expertise on

elements.text: Yeah I think writing two different articles would be better. But on a totally different topic that they still have expertise on

text:
Assuming I already have the topic from my content calendar, I
• Identify SMEs and draft interview Q's (if no SMEs are needed, skip this step)
• Do supplemental research on topic
• Conduct, record, transcribe interview
• Conduct keyword research
• 1st draft
• Show 1st draft to colleague for feedback
• 2nd draft
• Share 2nd draft with SME (I know this might be a controversial practice but it's required in my org)
• Edit
• Pick image for post
• Write social copy
• Publish online

elements.text: Assuming I already have the topic from my content calendar, I
Identify SMEs and draft interview Q's (if no SMEs are needed, skip this step)
Do supplemental research on topic
Conduct, record, transcribe interview
Conduct keyword research
1st draft
Show 1st draft to colleague for feedback
2nd draft
Share 2nd draft with SME (I know this might be a controversial practice but it's required in my org)
Edit
Pick image for post
Write social copy
Publish online

text: Quickly and efficiently can be the hard part. The more you do it, the quicker you'll become. I've found it helpful to give myself time limits on research-- topic and keyword and image--because it's easy to go down rabbit holes. Try to have reviewers stick to a set turn-around time and make it standard for all projects.

elements.text: Quickly and efficiently can be the hard part. The more you do it, the quicker you'll become. I've found it helpful to give myself time limits on research-- topic and keyword and image--because it's easy to go down rabbit holes. Try to have reviewers stick to a set turn-around time and make it standard for all projects.

1. A polite email to their CEO, CMO, Director and marketing manager.
2. A polite phone call to those people.
3. A C&D from your attorney
4. Follow-through on the next step you outlined in your C&D

text:
Hi everyone :wave:

I'm looking for some advice on how to map content to a customer journey.

Does anyone have any good examples of a customer journey audit?
Do you have a good solution for showing how content relates to the customer jobs, pains etc along the journey?

Any real-life examples/templates where this has worked really well would be appreciated.

elements.text: Hi everyone

I'm looking for some advice on how to map content to a customer journey.

Does anyone have any good examples of a customer journey audit?
Do you have a good solution for showing how content relates to the customer jobs, pains etc along the journey?

Any real-life examples/templates where this has worked really well would be appreciated.

text:
One approach that generates about 20 emails a day for us on one asset is to ungate the full content but include a gate for another asset that compliments the full content. Eg <https://www.datamigrationpro.com/data-migration-checklist-planner|https://www.datamigrationpro.com/data-migration-checklist-planner>

This has helped us get a No.1-2 slot for Google the last 10 years but still get emails collected.

attachments.fallback: Data Migration Pro: Data Migration Checklist: Planner + Template for Effective Data Migration Planning — Data Migration Pro
attachments.text: Data Migration Checklist: The Definitive Guide to Planning Your Next Data Migration Coming up with a data migration checklist for your data migration project is one of the most challenging tasks, particularly for the uninitiated. To help, I've compiled a list of 'must-do' activities that ​I've found
attachments.title: Data Migration Checklist: Planner + Template for Effective Data Migration Planning — Data Migration Pro

text: For our clients, we advise case studies as long form articles, and guides. So MOFU/BOFU stuff really because B2B readers at the TOFU phase can be a long ways off buyer intent.
